title: Who is the best Rock & Roll rhythm guitarist of all time and why? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A A few other great rhythm guitarists, some beyond R ’n’ R! Mabon Lewis “Teenie” Hodges is best known for his work with the Hi Rhythm section in the 1970s behind Al Green, Anne Peebles, Syl Johnson & others. Teenie Hodges was the house guitarist for Hi Records in Memphis who recorded a string of hits produced by Willie Mitchell and Teenie co-wrote several of these hits. After Al Green, Teenie would tour as part of the Hi Rhythm Section, which included his brothers Charles and Leroy, and record with Robert Cray, The Greatest by Cat Power and come back albums for Al Green & Syl Johndon. A talented musical family, he is also the Uncle of Drake. Soul Hero Teenie Hodges Dies at 68  Al Green with Teenie Hodges - Love & Happiness Another “in the pocket” guitarist is Jimmy Nolen of the James Brown Band/JBs who is known as “the claw” for a reason. He pioneered the “chicken scratch” style of guitar playing in the 60s featured on Papa’s Got a Brand new Bag. This almost percussive style of play featured on a whole host of 70s funk groups and 80s indie including Al Mc Kay of Earth Wind & Fire, Tower of Power, Chic, Orange Juice and was another source for many 80s hip hop samples. Another James Brown band member, Phelps “Catfish” Collins, brother of Bootsy is superb with both the JBs and Parliament.  The Boss with James Nolen Also keeping it in the family was Joseph "Nin-Nin" Reinhardt, the younger brother of the famous jazz guitarist Django Reinhardt and played rhythm behind his brother on the classic 1930s recordings Quintette du Hot Club de France. Both brothers were fine rhythm guitarists and Nin Nin was also a fine lead jazz guitar stylist in his own right. He would keep the swing-jazz flame alive after his brothers early death in 1953 and an old flame that still burns throughout Europe.  In the 50s Les Paul played Lead and Rhythm as did Mary Ford  In the early 70s Dr Feelgood in the UK featured Wilko Johnson from Canvay Island. Driven by Wilko Johnson’s driving Rhythm/lead guitar hybrid. Paul Weller, Andy Gill of Gang of Four made this the de riguer guitar style of choice for many post punk bands. Wilko has featured in Game of Thrones, survived a rare form of Pancreatic cancer and still threads the boards.   Roger Daltrey & Wilko Johnson - Going Back Home Chaz Jankel with Ian Dury and the Blockheads is another very fine rhythm guitarist from this era, an effortless player.  Brix Smith and all the guitarists with the Fall  Hungarian guitarist Gábor Szabó made several jazz-pop fusion albums in the late 60s. Live he was often backed by Jimmy Stewart. Jimmy disappeared into soundtrack work after Gábor Szabó and is estimated to have appeared on 1,200 recordings. His style is said to encompass the whole history of guitar from Segovia to even playing heavy metal alongside Tommy Bolin at a trade show in the 70s. Rock, Pop, Jazz, Blues features in his studio work. Jim Hall is another great lead and rhythm guitarist backing Ella Fitzgerald in the early 60s with every note perfectly placed. He is also the ultimate side man playing alongside Bill Evans, Sonny Rollins, Paul Desmond & Art Farmer.  Ricky Wilson’s driving rhythm was the backbone of many of the B52s hits - His guitar features on this 1979 song but he’s not on the 1987 video passing away from cancer in 1985.  Carlos Alomar would feature in the Apollo orchestra on 125 St NYC early in his career, even backing another Rock n Roll guitarist whose style was heavily Rhythm based, Chuck Berry. Carlos would spend many years of his career playing with David Bowie and on David Bowie produced side projects including this one.  Iggy Pop - The Passenger Lou Reed was often a very effective rhythm guitarist behind Sterling Morrison economical leads in the Velvet Underground but Johnny Ramone perfected the Rhythm as lead style of guitar play.  And finally Bob Marley’s rhythm is a rock solid foundation to many of the Wailers songs.

Engineer and producer Chris Thomas who, according to his wikipedia page (Chris Thomas (record producer) - Wikipedia) worked with the Beatles, Pink Floyd, Procol Harum, Roxy Music, Badfinger, Elton John, Paul McCartney, Pete Townshend, Pulp and the Pretenders, is on record as saying the best rhythm guitarist he ever worked with was Steve Jones of the Sex Pistols. Hands up everybody who was expecting *that* answer.
